Classic Movements

Classic movements from the 24-form and 42-form Tai Chi, integrating core combat principles and health benefits. These are the most representative forms of the art.

White Crane Spreads Wings

Advanced Movements

Traditional 108-form and specialized movements from various schools, requiring profound foundation and internal cultivation, embodying the deep essence of Tai Chi.

Cross Hands

In-Depth Analysis

Classic Movements Explained

Every movement holds profound meaning

Movement 1

Parting the Wild Horse's Mane

Ye Ma Fen Zong

The body turns, arms separate like a wild horse's mane, one hand wards upward while the other presses down. This movement embodies the use of "Peng" energy, a classic action in the 24-form Tai Chi.

Difficulty

‚≠ê‚≠ê

Core Energy

Ward Off

Key Point

Sink Shoulders

Application

Deflect Attack

Movement 2

White Crane Spreads Wings

Bai He Liang Chi

Arms separate up and down like a white crane spreading wings to fly. One hand supports upward while the other presses down. Body centered, clear distinction between substantial and insubstantial. Beautiful and graceful, one of the most ornamental movements in Tai Chi.

Difficulty

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

Core Energy

Pluck

Key Point

Clear Substantial

Application

Deflect & Lift

Movement 3

Brush Knee and Twist Step

Lou Xi Ao Bu

One hand brushes the knee while the other pushes forward simultaneously, advancing in bow stance. This movement embodies the core Tai Chi concept of "overcoming hardness with softness," deflecting the opponent's attack and counter-attacking smoothly.

Difficulty

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

Core Energy

Roll Back

Key Point

Coordinate Up/Down

Application

Brush & Strike

Movement 4

Playing the Pipa

Shou Hui Pi Pa

Hands positioned as if holding a pipa (lute), one arm wards forward while the other protects the chest. Taking form from playing this traditional instrument, graceful in posture and rich in meaning, embodying the Tai Chi principle of guarding the center.

Difficulty

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

Core Energy

Press

Key Point

Sink Shoulders

Application

Guard & Counter

Movement Overview

More Classic Movements

Tai Chi movements are rich and varied, each with unique characteristics

Step Back and Repulse Monkey

Dao Juan Gong

‚Ü©Ô∏è

Step back while turning body, arms swing alternately like rolling cloth. Embodying Tai Chi's concept of advancing through retreat.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Roll Back

Grasp the Sparrow's Tail

Zuo Lan Que Wei

üïäÔ∏è

Ward, Roll Back, Press, and Push combined into one, one of the most important movements in Tai Chi.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Four Methods

Single Whip

Dan Bian

üèá

One hand hooks, one hand presses, body centered like cracking a whip.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Press

Cloud Hands

Yun Shou

‚òÅÔ∏è

Hands move like rotating clouds, continuous and unbroken, body and hands as one, circular and natural.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Circular

High Pat on Horse

Gao Tan Ma

üêé

One hand reaches high, one hand presses to protect, like patting a horse forward, clear distinction between substantial and insubstantial.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Probe

Strike Ears with Fists

Shuang Feng Guan Er

‚õ∞Ô∏è

Both fists like twin peaks striking opponent's ears, combining hardness and softness.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Strike

Needle at Sea Bottom

Hai Di Zhen

‚öì

One hand thrusts down like a needle to the sea bottom, body sinks, overcoming hardness with softness.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Pluck

Flash the Arm

Shan Tong Bi

‚ö°

Dodge and extend arms, hands and feet coordinate, rapid transitions, embodying Tai Chi's agility.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Transition

Parry, Block, and Punch

Ban Lan Chui

üëä

Parry, block, and punch in sequence, combining offense and defense, balancing hardness and softness.

Difficulty ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê Attack & Defend
Practice Guide

Practice Key Points

Master the essentials, multiply your results

1

Body Centered, Clear Substantial and Insubstantial

Keep the body centered and natural, not leaning. Distinguish clearly between substantial and insubstantial in both feet, with clear weight transitions. Each movement must identify what is substantial and what is insubstantial, achieving clear distinction and natural transition.

2

Mind Leads Qi, Qi Moves Body

Mind as the guide, breathing coordinates with movement. Intent leads energy, energy leads power. Movements must have internal connection and continuity, not using excessive force, softness containing hardness.

3

Continuous and Circular, Upper and Lower Coordinate

Movements should be continuous and circular, like floating clouds and flowing water. Upper body and lower body must coordinate, hands and feet work together, whole body as one unit. Each movement must be complete, not broken or intermittent.

Common Questions

‚ùì

What if movements feel stiff?

Relax body and mind, do more warm-up exercises. When practicing, focus on sinking shoulders and dropping elbows, don't use excessive force. Start with slow movements, gradually relaxing muscles.

‚ùì

How to improve stability?

Strengthen stance practice like Wu Ji Stance. Focus on distinguishing substantial and insubstantial, slow weight transitions. Strengthen lower body training to improve stability.

‚ùì

How to achieve continuity?

Master the beginning, transition, and conclusion of each movement. When practicing, pay attention to connections between movements, avoid pauses. Practice complete sets frequently to build muscle memory.

‚ùì

How to coordinate breathing?

Use abdominal breathing, inhale when rising, exhale when sinking, inhale when opening, exhale when closing. Beginners can breathe naturally first, then coordinate breathing after becoming proficient. Never hold your breath.
